article.title: Dakota language
article.text:
{{Infobox language | name = Dakota | nativename = Dakhótiyapi, Dakȟótiyapi | pronunciation = {{IPA-sio|daˈkʰotijapi], [daˈqˣotijapi|}} | states = [[United States]], with some speakers in [[Canada]] | region = Primarily [[North Dakota]] and [[South Dakota]], but also northern [[Nebraska]], southern [[Minnesota]]; southern [[Manitoba]], southern [[Saskatchewan]] | ethnicity = [[Dakota people|Dakota]]
Santee, Sisseton, Yankton, Yanktonai | speakers = 290 | date = 2016 | ref = e19 | familycolor = American | fam1 = [[Siouan languages|Siouan]] | fam2 = [[Western Siouan languages|Western Siouan]] | fam3 = Mississippi Valley Siouan | fam4 = Dakotan | fam5 = [[Sioux language|Sioux]] | iso2 = dak | iso3 = dak | glotto = dako1258 | glottorefname = Dakota | notice = IPA }} '''Dakota''' (''Dakhótiyapi, Dakȟótiyapi''), also referred to as '''Dakhota''', is a [[Siouan languages|Siouan language]] spoken by the [[Dakota people]] of the [[Sioux]] tribes. Dakota is closely related to and mutually intelligible with the [[Lakota language]]. It is critically endangered, with only around 290 fluent speakers left out of an ethnic population of almost 20,000. ==Morphology== ===Nouns=== Dakota, similar to many Native American languages, is a mainly [[polysynthetic language]], meaning that different morphemes in the form of affixes can be combined to form a single word. Nouns in Dakota can be broken down into two classes, primitive and derivative. Primitive nouns are nouns whose origin cannot be deduced from any other word (for example ''make'' or earth, ''peta'' or fire, and ''ate'' or father), while derivative nouns are nouns that are formed in various ways from words of other grammatical categories. Primitive nouns stand on their own and are separate from other words. Derivative nouns, on the other hand, are formed by the addition of affixes to words in other grammatical categories, such as verbs, adjectives, and other nouns.{{cite book|last1=Riggs|first1=Stephen Return|last2=Dorsey|first2=James Owen|title=Dakota Grammar: With Texts and Ethnography|date=1983|publisher=Minnesota Historical Society Press|isbn=0873514726|edition=reprint|url=https://books.google.com/books?hl=en&lr=&id=vXhEGl6k4cEC&oi=fnd&pg=PR10&dq=dakota+grammar&ots=4wsDoPD1vm&sig=AumIZNYbJh4h8iput70xzjRIgU0#v=onepage&q=dakota%20grammar&f=false}} ===Verbs=== Verbs in Dakota can appropriate, through agglutination and synthesis, many of the pronominal, prepositional, and adverbial or modal affixes of the language. There are many verbal roots, all of which are only used once certain causative prefixes are added, forming [[participles]]. Like in English, Dakota verbs also have three [[persons]], the first, the second, and the third. Person is indicated through the addition (first and second person) or subtraction (third person, the verb is used in its simplest form) of personal pronoun affixes. There are two forms of tense in the language, the [[aorist]] (sometimes called the indefinite) and the [[future]]. In order to express the future tense, the words ''kta'' or ''kte'' are placed after the verb, much in contrast to expressing the aorist tense, which requires no marking, but is instead derived from the context of what is being said. ===Possessive pronouns and pronominal affixes=== In order to show possession in Dakota, a possessive pronoun must be prefixed onto whichever noun is being possessed. Two forms of possessive nouns occur, the natural class and the artificial or alienable class. Natural class pronouns express possession that cannot be alienated, and when prefixed to a noun, signifies the different parts of one's self. For example, the possessive natural article pronoun ''mi-'', which means "my," can be added to nouns such as "eye," in ''miista'', or "words," in ''mioie''. Meanwhile, artificial possessive pronouns are used to signify property and possessions that can be transferred or traded. For example, the artificial pronoun ''ta-'' or ''ti-'', which is equivalent to the singular her or him, can be prefixed onto nouns such as "bow," in ''tinazipe'', and "friend," in ''takodaku''. ==Syntax== ===Nouns and verbs=== Dakota is mainly a subject-object-verb (SOV) language, where nouns, whether they are the subject or object, always come before the verb. And when two nouns are used in the same clause, where one is the subject and the other is the object, the subject is most usually placed first. Verbs are also usually placed after adjectives that are used to qualify either the subject or the object and adverbs that qualify the verb. When additional words are used within a clause that are not either nouns or verbs, the nouns, both subject and object, are always placed at the beginning of the clause. ==Dialects== Dakota has two major dialects with two sub-dialects each (and minor variants, too):{{cite book | last = Ullrich | first = Jan | title = New Lakota Dictionary (Incorporating the Dakota Dialects of Yankton-Yanktonai and Santee-Sisseton) | publisher = Lakota Language Consortium |year=2008 | pages = | month = | isbn = 0-9761082-9-1 }} # '''Eastern Dakota''' ({{aka}} Santee-Sisseton or Dakhóta) #* Santee (Isáŋyáthi: Bdewákhaŋthuŋwaŋ,Formerly Mdewákhaŋthuŋwaŋ Waȟpékhute) #* Sisseton (Sisíthuŋwaŋ, Waȟpéthuŋwaŋ) # '''Western Dakota''' (a.k.a. Yankton-Yanktonai or Dakȟóta/Dakhóta, and erroneously classified, for a very long time, as "[[Nakota]]"for a report on the long-established blunder of misnaming "Nakota" the Yankton and the Yanktonai, see the article [[Nakota]]) #* Yankton (Iháŋktȟuŋwaŋ) #* Yanktonai (Iháŋktȟuŋwaŋna) #** Upper Yanktonai (Wičhíyena) The two dialects differ phonologically, grammatically, and to a large extent, also lexically. They are mutually intelligible to a high extent, although Western Dakota is lexically closer to the [[Lakota language]] with which it has higher mutual intelligibility. ==Writing systems== For a comparative table of the various writing systems conceived over time for the Sioux languages, cf. the specific section of the article [[Sioux language#Writing systems|Sioux language]]. ==Phonology== ===Vowels=== Dakota has five oral vowels, {{IPA|/a e i o u/}}, and three nasal vowels, {{IPA|/ã ĩ ũ/}}. {|class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" ! colspan="2" | ! [[Front vowel|Front]] ! [[Central vowel|Central]] ! [[Back vowel|Back]] |- ! rowspan="2" | high ! oral | {{IPA|i}} | | {{IPA|u}} |- ! nasal | {{IPA|ĩ}} | | {{IPA|ũ}} |- ! mid ! | {{IPA|e}} | | {{IPA|o}} |- ! rowspan="2" | low ! oral | | {{IPA|a}} | |- ! nasal | | {{IPA|ã}} | |} ===Consonants=== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" ! colspan="2" | ! [[Labial consonant|Labial]]
([[Labialization|-ized]]) ! [[Dental consonant|Dental]]/
[[Alveolar consonant|Alveolar]] ! [[Palatal consonant|Palatal]]
([[Palatalization (phonetics)|-ized]]) ! [[Velar consonant|Velar]]/
[[Uvular consonant|Uvular]] ! [[Glottal consonant|Glottal]] |- ! colspan="2" |[[Nasal consonant|Nasal]] | '''m''' {{IPA|[m]}} | '''n''' {{IPA|[n]}} | | | |- ! rowspan="4" |[[Stop consonant|Stop]] ! [[Aspirated consonant|aspirated]] | '''ph''' {{IPA|[pʰ]}}
'''pȟ''' {{IPA|[pˣ]}} | '''th''' {{IPA|[tʰ]}}
'''tȟ''' {{IPA|[tˣ]}} | '''čh''' {{IPA|[tʃʰ]}}
  | '''kh''' {{IPA|[kʰ]}}
'''kȟ''' {{IPA|[kˣ]}} | |- ! [[Voiceless consonant|voiceless]] | '''p''' {{IPA|[p]}} | '''t''' {{IPA|[t]}} | '''č''' {{IPA|[tʃ]}} | '''k''' {{IPA|[k]}} | ''''''' {{IPA|[ʔ]}} |- ! [[Ejective consonant|ejective]] | '''p'''' {{IPA|[pʼ]}} | '''t'''' {{IPA|[tʼ]}} | '''č'''' {{IPA|[tʃʼ]}} | '''k'''' {{IPA|[kʼ]}} | |- ! [[Voiced consonant|voiced]] | '''b''' {{IPA|[b]}} | '''d''' {{IPA|[d]}} | | '''g''' {{IPA|[ɡ]}} | |- ! rowspan="3" |[[Fricative consonant|Fricative]] ! [[Voiceless consonant|voiceless]] | | '''s''' {{IPA|[s]}} | '''š''' {{IPA|[ʃ]}} | '''ȟ''' {{IPA|[χ]}} | |- ! [[Ejective consonant|ejective]] | | '''s'''' {{IPA|[sʼ]}} | '''š'''' {{IPA|[ʃʼ]}} | '''ȟ'''' {{IPA|[χʼ]}} | |- ! [[Voiced consonant|voiced]] | | '''z''' {{IPA|[z]}} | '''ž''' {{IPA|[ʒ]}} | '''ǧ''' {{IPA|[ʁ]}} | |- ! colspan="2" |[[Approximant consonant|Approximant]] | '''w''' {{IPA|[w]}} | | '''y''' {{IPA|[j]}} | | '''h''' {{IPA|[h]}} |} ==Comparison of the dialects== ===Phonological differences=== In respect to phonology Eastern and Western Dakota differ particularly in consonant clusters. The table below gives the possible consonant clusters and shows the differences between the dialects: {|class="wikitable" ! colspan=11|Dakota consonant clusters |- ! colspan=8| ! Santee
Sisseton ! Yankton ! Yanktonai |- ! b ! ȟ ! k ! m ! p ! s ! š ! t ! h ! kmany Yankton speakers pronounce the following clusters in the same way as the Yanktonai (Ullrich, p. 5). ! g |- | bd | ȟč | kč | mn | pč | sč | šk | tk | align="center"| hm | align="center"| km | align="center"| gm |- | | ȟd | kp | | ps | sk | šd | | align="center"| hn | align="center"| kn | align="center"| gn |- | | ȟm | ks | | pš | sd | šb | | align="center"| hd | align="center"| kd | align="center"| gd |- | | ȟn | kš | | pt | sm | šn | | align="center"| hb | align="center"| kb | align="center"| gb |- | | ȟp | kt | | | sn | šp | | | | |- | | ȟt | | | | sp | št | | | | |- | | ȟb | | | | st | šb | | | | |- | | | | | | sb | | | | | |} The two dialects also differ in the diminutive suffix ('''-daŋ''' in Santee, and '''-na''' in Yankton-Yanktonai and in Sisseton) and in a number of other phonetic issues that are harder to categorize. The following table gives examples of words that differ in their phonology. {|class="wikitable" ! align="center" colspan="2" width="60"|Eastern Dakota ! align="center" colspan="2" width="60"|Western Dakota ! ''gloss'' |- ! align="center"|Santee ! align="center"|Sisseton ! align="center"|Yankton ! align="center"|Yanktonai ! |- | align="center"|hokšídaŋ | align="center"|hokšína | align="center" colspan="2"|hokšína | align="center"|''boy'' |- | align="center" colspan="2"|nína | align="center" |nína | align="center" |nína / dínain Upper Yanktonay | align="center" |''very'' |- | align="center" colspan="2"|hdá | align="center" |kdá | align="center" |gdá | align="center" |''to go back''more precisely: 'he/she/it is going (back)' (hence elsewhere). |- | align="center" colspan="2"|hbéza | align="center" |kbéza | align="center" |gbéza | align="center" |''ridged'' |- | align="center" colspan="2"|hnayáŋ | align="center" |knayáŋ | align="center" |gnayáŋ | align="center" |''to deceive'' |- | align="center" colspan="2"|hmúŋka | align="center" |kmúŋka | align="center" |gmúŋka | align="center" |''to trap'' |- | align="center" |ahdéškadaŋ | align="center" |ahdéškana | align="center" |akdéškana | align="center" |agdéškana | align="center" |''lizard'' |} ===Lexical differences=== There are also numerous lexical differences between the two Dakota dialects as well as between the sub-dialects. Yankton-Yanktonai is in fact lexically closer to the Lakota language than it is to Santee-Sisseton. The following table gives some examples: {|class="wikitable" ! align="center" width="100" rowspan="2"|English gloss ! align="center" width="100" rowspan="2"|Santee-Sisseton ! align="center" width="100" rowspan="2"|Yankton-Yanktonai ! align="center" colspan="2" width="200"|Lakota |- ! align="center"|Northern Lakota ! align="center"|Southern Lakota |- | align="center"|''child'' | align="center"|šičéča | align="center"|wakȟáŋyeža | align="center" colspan="2"|wakȟáŋyeža |- | align="center"|''knee'' | align="center"|hupháhu | align="center"|čhaŋkpé | align="center" colspan="2"|čhaŋkpé |- | align="center"|''knife'' | align="center"|isáŋ / mína | align="center"|mína | align="center" colspan="2"|míla |- | align="center"|''kidneys'' | align="center"|phakšíŋ | align="center"|ažúŋtka | align="center" colspan="2"|ažúŋtka |- | align="center"|''hat'' | align="center"|wapháha | align="center"|wapȟóštaŋ | align="center" colspan="2"|wapȟóštaŋ |- | align="center"|''still'' | align="center"|hináȟ | align="center"|naháŋȟčiŋ | align="center" colspan="2"|naháŋȟčiŋ |- | align="center"|''man'' | align="center"|wičhášta | align="center"|wičháša | align="center" colspan="2"|wičháša |- | align="center"|''hungry'' | align="center"|wótehda | align="center"|dočhíŋ | align="center" colspan="2"|ločhíŋ |- | align="center"|''morning'' | align="center"|haŋȟ'áŋna | align="center"|híŋhaŋna | align="center"|híŋhaŋna | align="center"|híŋhaŋni |- | align="center"|''to shave'' | align="center"|kasáŋ | align="center"|kasáŋ | align="center"|kasáŋ | align="center"|glak'óǧa |} ===Grammatical differences=== Yankton-Yanktonai has the same three [[Apophony|ablaut]] grades as Lakota (a, e, iŋ),which means that, in many words ending in '''-a''' (which are conventionally cited, in Ullrich's dictionary (cf. pp. 699/700), with a capitalized final '''–A/Aŋ'''), the same '''-a''' turns into '''-e''' or into '''-iŋ''' when some circumstances occur (the word is the last in a sentence, or is modified by suffixes that trigger the ablaut, or, still, is followed by a word that triggers the ablaut, as well). while in Santee-Sisseton there are only two (a, e). This significantly impacts word forms, especially in fast speech and it is another reason why Yankton-Yanktonai has better mutual intelligibility with Lakota than with Santee-Sisseton. Some examples: {|class="wikitable" ! align="center" width="100"|English gloss | to go | align="center"|I shall go | to go back | align="center"|he/she/it will go back |- ! align="center" width="100"|santee-sisseton | align="center"|y'''á''' | align="center"|bd'''é''' kte | align="center"|hd'''á''' | align="center"|hd'''é''' kte |- ! align="center" width="100"|yankton-yanktonai | align="center"|y'''á''' | align="center"|mn'''íŋ''' kte | align="center"|kd'''á'''/gd'''á''' | align="center"|kn'''íŋ'''/gn'''íŋ''' kte |- ! align="center" width="100"|lakota | align="center"|y'''á''' | align="center"|mn'''íŋ''' kte | align="center"|gl'''á''' | align="center"|gn'''íŋ''' kte |} There are other grammatical differences between the dialects. == Learning Dakota: language revitalization efforts == ===Software and mobile apps for learning Dakhóta=== A ''Dakota 1'' app was previously available for [[iPhone]], [[iPad]], and other [[iOS]] devices.{{Cite web | title = App Shopper: Dakota 1 (Education) | accessdate = 2012-09-12 | url = http://appshopper.com/education/dakota-1 }} The [[Association on American Indian Affairs]] website offers an extensive selection of Dakotah learning resources, including CDs, DVDs, flashcards, and software.{{Cite web |title = AAIA Native Language Program |accessdate = 2013-01-19 |url = http://aaialanguageprogram.org/ |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20121201005528/http://aaialanguageprogram.org/ |archivedate = 2012-12-01 |df = }} ===Curriculum, textbooks, and other materials for teaching and learning Dakhóta=== A ''Level 1 Speak Dakota!'' textbook is available from the [[Dakhóta Iápi Okhódakičhiye]]. Developed by Dakota language speakers, teachers, and linguists, the textbook is the first fully illustrated Dakota language textbook that is linguistically and pedagogically consistent. Dakota language learning materials are also available on their website.{{Cite web | title = Dakhóta Iápi Okhódakičhiye/Dakota Language Society | accessdate = 2014-08-29 | url = http://dakhota.org/ }} ==Notable speakers== *[[Dallas Goldtooth]], [[Dakota people|Dakota]] member of the [[1491s]], language teacher and environmental activist *[[Gwen Westerman]], Dakota educator, writer and artist ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==Bibliography== * DeMallie, Raymond J. (2001). Sioux until 1850. In R. J. DeMallie (Ed.), ''Handbook of North American Indians: Plains'' (Vol. 13, Part 2, pp. 718–760). W. C. Sturtevant (Gen. Ed.). Washington, D.C.: Smithsonian Institution. {{ISBN|0-16-050400-7}}. * Parks, Douglas R.; & Rankin, Robert L. (2001). The Siouan languages. In ''Handbook of North American Indians: Plains'' (Vol. 13, Part 1, pp. 94–114). Washington, D.C.: Smithsonian Institution. * de Reuse, Willem J. (1987). [https://kuscholarworks.ku.edu/dspace/handle/1808/509 One hundred years of Lakota linguistics (1887–1987)]. ''Kansas Working Papers in Linguistics'', ''12'', 13-42. * de Reuse, Willem J. (1990). [https://kuscholarworks.ku.edu/dspace/handle/1808/441 A supplementary bibliography of Lakota languages and linguistics (1887–1990)]. ''Kansas Working Papers in Linguistics'', ''15'' (2), 146-165. (Studies in Native American languages 6). *Rood, David S.; & Taylor, Allan R. (1996). ''Sketch of Lakhota, a Siouan language''. In ''Handbook of North American Indians: Languages'' (Vol. 17, pp. 440–482). Washington DC: Smithsonian Institution. *{{cite journal|last1=Parks|first1= D.R. |last2= DeMallie|first2= R.J. |date=1992|title= Sioux, Assiniboine, and Stoney Dialects: A Classification |journal=Anthropological Linguistics |volume= 34|issue= 1–4|pages=233–255|jstor=30028376}} *Riggs, S.R., & Dorsey, J.O. (Ed.). (1973). Dakota grammar, texts, and ethnography. Minneapolis: Ross & Haines, Inc. *Shaw, P.A. (1980). Theoretical issues in Dakota phonology and morphology. New York: Garland Publishing, Inc. * Ullrich, Jan. (2008). [http://www.lakotadictionary.org/nldo.php New Lakota Dictionary & Incorporating the Dakota Dialects of Santee-Sisseton and Yankton-Yanktonai] (Lakota Language Consortium). {{ISBN|0-9761082-9-1}}. == External links == * [http://cdm.bostonathenaeum.org/cdm/search/collection/p16057coll24/searchterm/Dakota/field/langua/mode/all/conn/and/order/nosort Dakota Language Texts], from the [http://cdm.bostonathenaeum.org/cdm/landingpage/collection/p16057coll24 Boston Athenæum: Schoolcraft Collection of Books in Native American Languages. Digital Collection.] {{Siouan languages}} {{Languages of Minnesota}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Dakota Language}} [[Category:Dakota culture]] [[Category:Native American language revitalization]] [[Category:Western Siouan languages]]
